abstract: with the united states reaching a once-unthinkable coronavirus pandemic death toll of 400,000 people on tuesday, the eve of his inauguration as president, joseph r. biden jr. is assuming the role of mourner in chief and projecting an air of command of the issue that has vexed the trump administration for the past year.

abstract: people in the united states have been dying of covid-19 at the highest rate of the pandemic. the new milestone of 400,000 deaths, reached on tuesday, is the equivalent of wiping out a city the size of oakland, calif. it is on the order of sept. 11 deaths more than a hundred times over. at that scale, the human brain compensates with a defense that political psychologists call “psychic numbing.”
headline: one day in the pandemic: portraits of lives cut short.

abstract: the coronavirus pandemic has pushed millions of americans into poverty and stripped more than 5.4 million of them of their health insurance, according to a study by families usa, a nonpartisan consumer advocacy group.
headline: medical tourism is drawing patients, even in a pandemic.

abstract: janet l. yellen, president-elect joseph r. biden’s nominee to be treasury secretary, said at her confirmation hearing on tuesday that investing in vaccine distribution and expanded jobless benefits will provide the biggest “bang” for the economy in a future stimulus package to help americans get through the current “dark” economic time.
headline: janet yellen’s confirmation hearing for treasury secretary centers on the pandemic.

abstract: in the past, lawmakers tended to preach allegiance to full employment — the lowest jobless rate an economy can sustain without stoking high inflation or other instabilities — while pulling back fiscal and monetary support before hitting that target as they worried that a more patient approach would cause price spikes and other problems.
headline: the new, singular focus in washington: restoring the pre-pandemic job market.

abstract: britain’s theaters have been in financial crisis since the coronavirus pandemic forced them to shut last march. although a few have hosted performances for socially distanced audiences, most have only survived through a combination of crisis grants and layoffs.
headline: theaters aid britain’s pandemic-struck courts, and not everyone is applauding.

abstract: dr. rachel levine, who is currently pennsylvania’s health secretary, would become the first transgender federal official confirmed by the senate.
headline: biden announces his picks for senior positions in health and in transportation.

abstract: skylar mack, an american college student, was released last week after spending more than a month behind bars. she said, “i deserved it.”
headline: student who was jailed for breaking quarantine in caymans apologizes

abstract: the russian government is considering issuing coronavirus health certificates that could ease travel and commerce for people who have been vaccinated or who have antibodies from surviving the disease, while sharply limiting the liberties of others — an idea that has also been floated in the european union and by private companies.
headline: russia mulls ‘covid passports’ to let people with some immunity travel more easily.

abstract: it’s more contagious than the original and spreading quickly. upgrade your mask and double down on precautions to protect yourself.
headline: what you can do to avoid the new coronavirus variant right now

abstract: the government survived a near-collapse, but it remained unclear just what matteo renzi, the ambitious former prime minister, hoped to gain by provoking it.
headline: as political crisis meets pandemic, italians wonder, why?

abstract: president-elect joseph r. biden jr. will participate in a ceremony at the lincoln memorial to honor the americans who have died from covid-19.
headline: watch live: biden honors lives lost to covid-19

abstract: researchers found that the variant originated in california and showed up in more than half of samples tested last week by researchers in los angeles.
headline: new california variant may be driving virus surge there, study suggests

abstract: at least 19 capitol police officers either tested positive for the coronavirus or were found through contact tracing to have been exposed since a mob of trump supporters — most of them not wearing masks — attacked the capitol on jan. 6, according to three people familiar with the matter.
headline: more capitol police officers test positive for coronavirus after riot.

abstract: a new modeling study hints that odor-based screens could quash outbreaks. but some experts are skeptical it would work in the real world.
headline: could a smell test screen people for covid?

abstract: joe biden held a ceremony to remember the 400,000 americans who have died during the pandemic.
headline: coronavirus briefing: what happened today

abstract: president-elect joseph r. biden jr. arrived in washington on tuesday and led a national mourning for americans killed by the coronavirus pandemic as the death toll topped 400,000, a gesture to the tragedy the country had endured even as he pledged that light would pierce the darkness.
headline: ‘to heal, we must remember,’ biden says at ceremony for coronavirus victims.

abstract: by dropping or suspending the requirement that applicants submit standardized test scores, colleges have cut into the college board’s business model.
headline: retooling during pandemic, the sat will drop essay and subject tests

abstract: the classic combination in mala of sichuan peppercorns and chiles makes for a sensation that is spicy, tingly and spicy again.
headline: i lost my appetite because of covid. this sichuan flavor brought it back.

abstract: the united states needs a vaccination plan that treats the coronavirus less like the seasonal flu and more like an act of bioterrorism.

abstract: dr. robert redfield predicted the “worst is yet to come” with the coronavirus and expressed frustration with the politicization of mask-wearing and mitigation efforts.

abstract: a new variant of the coronavirus has caused concern in the united states because it’s so contagious and spreading fast. to avoid it, you’ll need to double down on the pandemic precautions that have kept you safe so far.
headline: here are steps you can take to protect yourself from the new coronavirus variant.

abstract: “we will have literally nothing left to give as of friday,” mayor bill de blasio said. the next shipment is expected on tuesday.
headline: n.y.c. is days away from running out of vaccine

abstract: zimbabwe’s minister of foreign affairs and international trade, sibusiso busi moyo, has died, the office of the president said on wednesday. the cause was complications related to covid-19. mr. moyo became the fourth high-ranking official in zimbabwe to succumb to the virus since the start of the pandemic.
headline: zimbabwe’s foreign minister dies from covid-19.

abstract: italy plans to take legal action against the american drugmaker pfizer for delays in the delivery of coronavirus vaccines, domenico arcuri, italy’s special commissioner for the pandemic, said in a statement on tuesday night.
headline: italy says it will sue pfizer over delays in vaccine delivery.

abstract: eastern iowa airport will ask a handful of short screening questions and take the temperature of each departing passenger.
headline: an iowa airport will conduct coronavirus screenings of all outgoing passengers.

abstract: in his inaugural address, president biden spoke of a return to the ordinary discord of democracy, with a reminder that “politics doesn’t have to be a raging fire, destroying everything in its path.”
headline: a call for unity to a nation facing a pandemic and division

abstract: president joe biden began putting his plan to combat a pandemic into action.

abstract: laboratory studies of mutations circulating in south africa suggest they may dodge some of the body’s immune responses.
headline: emerging coronavirus variants may pose challenges to vaccines

abstract: revenues for the trump organization fell nearly 38 percent in 2020 as the coronavirus took a steep toll on the hospitality industry. mar-a-lago was a bright spot.
headline: trump financial disclosure reveals a business upended by the pandemic

abstract: ms. sakal had worked as an interpreter in hawaii for nearly 40 years.
headline: patty sakal, a.s.l. interpreter for virus updates, dies of covid at 62

abstract: seeking to unify the global response to the coronavirus, president biden on his first day in office retracted a decision by the trump administration to withdraw from the world health organization.
headline: biden restores ties with the world health organization that were cut by trump.

abstract: president biden, pledging a “full-scale wartime effort” to combat the coronavirus pandemic, signed a string of executive orders and presidential directives on thursday aimed at combating the worst public health crisis in a century, including new requirements for masks on interstate planes, trains and buses and for international travelers to quarantine after arriving in the united states.
headline: biden rolls out ‘full-scale, wartime’ coronavirus strategy, including requiring masks on some planes, trains and buses.

abstract: president biden is using thursday, his first full day in office, to go on the offensive against the coronavirus, with a 200-page national strategy that includes aggressive use of executive authority to protect workers, advance racial equity and ramp up the manufacturing of test kits, vaccines and supplies.
headline: biden is unveiling a federal pandemic response strategy, which trump resisted.

abstract: some patients could be living with the aftereffects for years to come. recent research into another persistent, mysterious disease might help us understand how to treat them.

abstract: a times reporter caught the coronavirus during the new york city outbreak last april. but the acute phase of the illness was just the beginning.

abstract: declining a covid-19 shot because you think it should go to someone else won’t help anyone.

abstract: it’s too soon to know. but some recent data, especially from specific groups, is cause for worry.

abstract: confirmed coronavirus cases from new variants found first in britain, then in south africa, brazil and the united states have people worried about whether vaccines can protect against altered versions of the virus. experts said in interviews that so far vaccines are capable of providing that protection.

abstract: patty sakal, an american sign language interpreter who translated updates about the coronavirus for deaf hawaiians, died on friday of complications related to covid-19. she was 62.

abstract: china’s coronavirus vaccines were supposed to deliver a geopolitical win that showcased the country’s scientific prowess and generosity. instead, in some places, they have set off a backlash.

abstract: when mount sinai hospital opened its center for post-covid care in may, it was the first such facility in the united states. the doctors there expected to treat patients who had been severely ill or hospitalized. by that point, three months into the pandemic, they knew that the coronavirus could cause harm to many parts of the body beyond the airways where infections most commonly begin. and they knew that medical treatments meant to save patients’ lives could also take a toll. recovery from having been put on a ventilator, in particular, could be a lengthy process.
headline: what if you never get better from covid-19?

abstract: with the snap of the snare drums, new orleanians take joyous turns high-stepping and chicken strutting, dressed in the finery of their social clubs and krewes. the celebration, shown on a 30-second public service announcement, is one of numerous efforts around the country to persuade people to get inoculated against the coronavirus. but its homegrown approach, using neighborhood personas and invoking local carnival culture, may make it particularly effective, say experts in vaccine hesitance and behavioral change.
headline: a vaccine ad invokes the culture of mardi gras to reduce hesitancy.

abstract: wealthy nations have been hoarding the scant supplies of coronavirus vaccines in an effort to save lives and revive their devastated economies.

abstract: vaccines by moderna and pfizer-biontech effectively protect recipients. but in a worrying sign, they are slightly less effective against a variant found in south africa.

abstract: president biden addresses the fight against the coronavirus pandemic from the white house.
headline: watch live: biden delivers remarks on the fight against covid-19

abstract: the company had its first $5 billion quarter for its gaming business, as people looked for entertainment at home and microsoft launched the long awaited new generation of its xbox console.
headline: microsoft profits jump 33 percent as pandemic continues shift to cloud computing.

abstract: vice president kamala harris received her second dose of the moderna coronavirus vaccine on tuesday at the national institutes of health in bethesda, md., saying the vaccine is “something that can save your life.”
headline: harris receives second vaccine dose

abstract: countries tighten their borders as they attempt to seal themselves off from new variants.
headline: coronavirus briefing: what happened today

abstract: president biden announced on tuesday that his administration was working on a deal to secure the doses of coronavirus vaccine from pfizer and moderna by the end of the summer. the deal is unlikely to accelerate the current pace of vaccination for several months.
headline: biden administration orders 200 million more vaccine doses

abstract: the hall of fame coach, now at iona college, had previously pushed for the season to be delayed.
headline: rick pitino, who pushed to delay college basketball season, tested positive for the coronavirus

abstract: here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
headline: impeachment, coronavirus, spring training: your tuesday evening briefing

abstract: representative david clark, who represents a suburban district northeast of atlanta, was led from the chamber on the orders of the house speaker and a fellow republican.
headline: a state representative is kicked out of georgia’s house chamber after refusing a coronavirus test.

abstract: authorities say steven r. brandenburg, a 46-year-old hospital pharmacist, attempted to spoil the doses of the moderna vaccine by removing them from a hospital refrigeration unit.
headline: a wisconsin pharmacist will plead guilty to attempting to spoil hundreds of vaccine doses.

abstract: president biden said the number of coronavirus vaccines reaching the states would rise next week and a deal was near to provide enough shots to vaccinate nearly all americans by the end of summer.
headline: biden pledges to speed flow of vaccines to the states

abstract: see the risk of contracting the disease in your county, and read our county-specific guidance for common activities to help you lower your risk and protect your community.
headline: see covid-19 risk in your county and a guide for daily life near you

abstract: an emergency worker in florida forged vaccine screening and consent forms for missing vaccines to cover up their theft, the authorities said.
headline: ‘paramedic of the year’ is arrested after covid-19 vaccine theft, sheriff says

abstract: as vaccine production falls behind schedule, and the european union lags in inoculating people, brussels and london are lobbing threats and accusations at each other.
headline: e.u. and u.k. fighting over scarce vaccines

abstract: when you learn more about the people the nation has lost, the sense of devastation can be overwhelming. it was for me.
headline: after nearly a year of reporting on covid, focusing on just one day

abstract: the spread of other dangerous germs is surging — a result, in part, of the chaotic response to the pandemic.
headline: with all eyes on covid-19, drug-resistant infections crept in

abstract: with vaccinations underway, and as multiple new coronavirus variants begin to spread, we check in on the state of the pandemic.
headline: why are u.s. coronavirus cases falling? and will the trend last?

abstract: the mayor of moscow, sergei s. sobyanin, declared on wednesday that the coronavirus pandemic was easing in the russian capital, and abruptly lifted most of the remaining restrictions in place in the city, saying the focus must shift to strengthening the economy.
headline: moscow mayor lifts restrictions, declaring the pandemic is ‘on the decline.’

headline: millions meant for public health threats were diverted elsewhere, watchdog says

abstract: gov. gretchen whitmer of michigan opened her annual state of the state speech on wednesday by pleading with lawmakers to find common ground in fighting the staggering effects of the coronavirus pandemic in the state.
headline: whitmer pleads with michigan lawmakers to find common ground amid the pandemic.

abstract: in pleas for more money from capitol hill, the advisers said the united states was still facing shortages of protective gear and other supplies.
headline: biden advisers say u.s. will remain vulnerable to covid unless congress acts

abstract: public health workers in josephine county, ore., said they had walked from car to car, giving shots to drivers with vaccine doses that would expire in six hours.
headline: health workers, stuck in the snow, administer coronavirus vaccine to stranded drivers

abstract: women who end a pregnancy after 12 weeks could still face prison or fines. abortion rights advocates say more change is needed.
headline: thailand legalizes abortion in 1st trimester but keeps other restrictions

abstract: the virus’s strangest symptom has opened new doors to understanding our most neglected sense.
headline: what can covid-19 teach us about the mysteries of smell?

abstract: i hope that a year from now this is a piece people point to as an overreaction. i hope.
headline: the new virus variants make the next 6 weeks crucial

abstract: the author of “the big short” and “moneyball” takes on a frightening subject in his new book “the premonition”: how to prevent a viral outbreak even worse than covid-19.
headline: from michael lewis, a ‘superhero story’ about the pandemic

abstract: some patients struggling with covid-19 develop antibodies against their own tissues, scientists have found.
headline: how the coronavirus turns the body against itself

abstract: public health workers found themselves stuck in a snowstorm on an oregon highway this week, with only six hours to get the coronavirus vaccines they were carrying to people waiting for their shots about 30 miles away.
headline: health workers were stuck in the snow in oregon with vaccines, so they improvised.

abstract: a civil rights activist once called los angeles an “imperfect paradise.”
headline: ‘get your shot here’: at dodger stadium, the lines are for vaccine, not beer.

abstract: the well section set out to answer some of the most commonly asked questions about the coronavirus vaccine, and a few that are perhaps not so common. using an experimental tool that relies on machine learning, you can even try posing a few questions of your own.
headline: check this out to get your every covid-19 vaccine question answered. really.

abstract: chancellor angela merkel will convene the governors of germany’s 16 states, along with representatives of pharmaceutical companies to discuss the country’s troubled vaccination scheme, after her health minister, jens spahn, warned that the country is facing another 10 weeks of vaccine shortages.
headline: germany says vaccine shortages are likely to last another 10 weeks, and other news from around the world.

abstract: the european central bank on thursday effectively warned eurozone banks to clean up their acts, saying that many are complacent about losses they may suffer from a surge in problem loans caused by the pandemic.
headline: eurozone banks are underestimating risks from the pandemic, e.c.b. warns.

abstract: tanzania’s president cast doubt on coronavirus vaccines and other measures to curb the spread of the pandemic, doubling down on his line of reasoning that only god could protect the east african nation. his comments came a day before the world health organization urged the nation to take measures to protect its population.
headline: tanzania’s president says ‘vaccines don’t work,’ earning a rebuff from the w.h.o.

abstract: the coronavirus can warp the body’s defenses in many ways — disarming early warning systems, for example, or causing immune cells to misfire. but a spate of new studies suggests another insidious consequence: the infection can provoke the production of antibodies that mistakenly attack the patient’s own tissues instead of the virus.
headline: here’s how the coronavirus turns the body against itself.

abstract: the first full week of the biden presidency has unfolded with a certain rhythm, with each day putting a spotlight on a new policy theme. president biden has addressed american manufacturing, racial equity and climate change since monday.
headline: biden plans to address health care, the latest policy theme to be showcased at the white house this week.

abstract: census bureau data show how households have struggled to stay current on rent and mortgage payments during the pandemic.
headline: people of color face the most pandemic housing insecurity

abstract: mississippi officials are proud their prisons have some of the country’s lowest infection rates, but they’re not testing inmates without coronavirus symptoms.
headline: mississippi prison officials tout low rates of covid. the reason may be fewer tests.

abstract: faced with the urgent need to protect nurses and other frontline workers, labor organizations are pushing hospitals to do more.
headline: health care unions find a voice in the pandemic

abstract: health officials in south carolina said on thursday that they had detected two cases of a more contagious variant of the coronavirus that emerged in south africa. it was the first report of that variant being detected in the united states.
headline: the variant that emerged in south africa is reported in the u.s. for the first time.

abstract: president biden is expected to sign executive orders expanding access to health care through the affordable care act and expand abortion access.
headline: watch live: biden signs executive orders on health care

abstract: the european union is pushing for astrazeneca to supply more doses of its covid-19 vaccine after announcing on wednesday that it would cut deliveries by 60 percent due to manufacturing issues.
headline: e.u. pushes for astrazeneca to provide more vaccines

abstract: president biden took executive action to expand health care access by strengthening the affordable care act and reopening enrollment. he also moved to protect reproductive rights and expand abortion access.
headline: health care orders undo ‘damage trump has done,’ biden says

abstract: when hospital administrators and politicians’ spouses get immunized before people more at risk, it undermines confidence in the system.

abstract: an early analysis in britain found that the vaccine had an efficacy rate of nearly 90 percent. but in a small south africa trial, the efficacy rate dropped to just under 50 percent.

abstract: the w.h.o. and the c.d.c. provide differing views, and experts partly blame a lack of data because expectant mothers have been excluded from clinical trials.

abstract: rabbi chaim kanievsky, 93, can’t use a phone. he rarely leaves his house. his family says he has never successfully made a cup of tea. his closest aides think he doesn’t know the name of israel’s prime minister. he studies the torah for, give or take, 17 hours a day.
headline: he’s israel’s ‘prince of torah.’ but to some, he’s the king of covid.

abstract: we want to hear from those who have lost a teacher, a brother, a bandmate or any of the other more than 430,000 americans who have died in the pandemic.

abstract: a new study suggests that protective antibodies can be transferred through the placenta, and the baby may receive more of them if a mother is infected with covid earlier in her pregnancy.

abstract: the medium can be just as important as the message.

abstract: the university of california, davis, is providing free testing, masks and quarantine housing to tens of thousands of people who live nearby.

abstract: vaccine development exceeded everyone’s expectations. but the next few months will still bring many sick people — and doctors have woefully few drugs with which to treat them.

abstract: south carolina was already experiencing one of the worst coronavirus outbreaks in the nation when officials got word this week of an alarming development: a new, more concerning variant of the virus, originally identified in south africa, had been detected in the state.
headline: scientists see the discovery of the south africa variant in south carolina as a ‘pivotal moment.’

abstract: with nearly eight million people, or 11.7 percent of the population, having already received their first shot, britain’s pace of vaccination is the fastest of any large nation in the world. only israel and the united arab emirates are moving faster.

abstract: already criticized for a slow rollout for its 27 members, brussels retreated on export controls linked to ireland and brexit.

abstract: the situation highlights the challenge posed by the two vaccines that have so far been approved in the united states — both need to be kept cold.
headline: when a hospital refrigerator in seattle broke, nurses gave 1,600 vaccine shots to anyone they could find.

abstract: when normal life recedes, ideology fills the vacuum.

abstract: several indicators, including a 40 percent drop in average new reported cases, are encouraging. but transmission is still dangerously high, and new variants could upend progress.

abstract: rich countries are buying up coronavirus vaccines, leaving poorer regions vulnerable — and as potential breeding grounds for variants, like one found in south africa, that could make vaccines less effective.

abstract: his breakthrough helped millions get their results quickly in the early days of the pandemic, when tests were scarce and lines were long.

abstract: presidents have played politics with women’s lives for long enough.

headline: australia locks down a whole city after finding a single new coronavirus case.

abstract: data showed that while 24% of city residents are black, only 11% of vaccine recipients were. white new yorkers received a disproportionate share of the shots.

headline: new york city postpones vaccine appointments as a snowstorm approaches.

abstract: mayor bill de blasio said data on the city’s vaccine rollout showed black and latino new yorkers being vaccinated at starkly lower rates than white residents, who have gotten a disproportionate share of the shots.

abstract: in this lesson, students will explore vaccination campaigns of the past two centuries. then, based on their findings, they will make recommendations to president biden on how to improve the current vaccine rollout.
headline: lesson of the day: ‘a look at past vaccine drives: smallpox, polio and the swine flu’

abstract: the country’s short, sharp responses have repeatedly subdued the virus and allowed a return to near normalcy. now its model is being applied to perth, its fourth-largest city.
headline: one case, total lockdown: australia’s lessons for a pandemic world

abstract: the police in china have broken up a counterfeiting ring that they say manufactured and sold more than 3,000 fake coronavirus vaccines across the country, xinhua, china’s state-run news agency, reported on monday.
headline: the chinese police arrest more than 80 people suspected of manufacturing fake vaccines.

abstract: like other celebrities, basketball stars can help build trust in taking the shot.

abstract: no matter where you live or how high your socioeconomic status, climate change can endanger your health, both physical and mental, now and in the future.

abstract: berlin — as germany’s leaders gather in berlin to discuss the lagging vaccinations in the country and across the european union, the bloc got some good news monday morning when the pharmaceutical company biontech announced that it would make 75 million extra doses available in coming months.
headline: biontech promises 75 million additional vaccine doses for the e.u.

abstract: monday: a new york times interactive map shows the uneven toll of the virus, neighborhood by neighborhood, on the nation’s most populous county.

abstract: robinhood, the stock platform that put restraints on trading of shares like the video game retailer gamestop and the movie theater chain amc after a frenzy of buying and selling last week, has decreased the number of companies with trading restrictions to eight from 50, according to an update on its website.
headline: robinhood pares its list of companies with trading restrictions to 8 from 50.

abstract: new york found itself in the midst of a nor’easter that was on track to be one of the city’s heaviest storms ever.

abstract: the deputy commissioner for public health at the new york state health department resigned in late summer. soon after, the director of its bureau of communicable disease control also stepped down. so did the medical director for epidemiology. last month, the state epidemiologist said she, too, would be leaving.
headline: sidelined by cuomo, nine top new york state health officials have quit in recent months.

abstract: people who have already been sick with covid-19 should still be vaccinated, experts say, but they may experience intense side effects even after one dose.

abstract: the country has one of africa’s better vaccination rates: just under one-quarter of its population has been fully inoculated.

abstract: no cases of the new coronavirus variant have been confirmed in the u.s., but leaders said they were using existing safeguards and watching closely.

abstract: getting a vaccination remains the best line of defense against covid-19, the nation’s top two health leaders said on sunday.

abstract: officials in scotland confirmed on monday that six cases of the omicron variant of the coronavirus had been recorded in the country and that some of those infected had not traveled recently, suggesting that there was community transmission. but they said there was no evidence that the transmission was “sustained or widespread.”

abstract: officials said that some of the cases of the omicron coronavirus variant were not linked to travel, suggesting community transmission, but that there was no evidence that transmission was sustained or widespread.

abstract: mutations can work together to make a virus more fearsome, but they can also cancel one another out. this phenomenon, called epistasis, is why scientists are reluctant to speculate on omicron.
